title: The Atlantic Monthly

renewed-issues.note: CCE lists this issue under renewals for volume 154.

renewed-contributions.title: The Road Away From Revolution
renewed-contributions.note: This article was renewed as a book, and the CCE renewal entry does not mention the Atlantic; however, the Atlantic article and the booklet appear to have been published around the same time, and likely have the same content.

renewed-contributions.title: The Merchant Marine and the Young Fellow
How Does it Feel to be Free
The Sheepherder Calls it a Day
A Petit Premiere in the Mt. Blanc Massif
If One Voice, Not Another, Must Speak First (Preludes to Definition)
If I Should Be Queen: Poem
The Grandpa of All the Fishes
The Man Who Won the War
A Tooth for Paul Revere
renewed-contributions.note: We are not sure this story appeared in this issue.  It did appear in the December 1937 issue, and there is another renewal for that.

renewed-contributions.title: Planning in an Economy of Abundance
War and Football, Mr. Pennyfeather Speaks Out
It Seems There Were a Jew an Irishman (Irishman and a Jew)
The Ballad of the Duke's Mercy
What Luck! An Autobiography
renewed-contributions.note: A 1967 renewal registration for Milne's Autobiography is likely to cover this article, which is the first-published version of that book's first part.

renewed-contributions.title: What Luck! An Autobiography
renewed-contributions.note: A 1967 renewal registration for Milne's Autobiography is likely to cover this article, which is the first-published version of that book's second part.

renewed-contributions.title: What Luck! An Autobiography
renewed-contributions.note: A 1967 renewal registration for Milne's Autobiography is likely to cover this article, which is the first-published version of that book's third part.

renewed-contributions.title: Ernest Hemingway: Bourdon Gauge of Morale
The Isles of Spice and Lilies
Phillips Brooks
renewed-contributions.note: Also noted in the 1969 renewal for the 1941 book Golden Yesterdays, which included a revised version of this article.

renewed-contributions.title: The Winner Loses: A Picture of Occupied France
The Seal Eskimos-Kabloona, the White Man
King William Land-Kabloona, the White Man
With the German Armies: A War Diary
Why I Live at the P. O.
Sir Richard Burton's Wife: Gypsy's Prophecy
Sir Richard Burton's Wife: The Newlywed
Inner Song While Watching a Square Dance From Trial by Time
Forty-Nine Days from Boston, From On the Trail of the Money Bird
Sir Richard Burton's Wife: The Widow
My Yankee Mother
renewed-contributions.note: A 1969 renewal for this 1942 book mentions that chapter 21 was first published in the July 1941 issue of The Atlantic Monthly.  We do not know the title under which it was published.

renewed-contributions.title: The Collected Works of Mrs. Peter Willoughby
When I Was Twenty I & II
Men Without a Country
renewed-contributions.note: The renewal for this article credits it to Nordhoff, but the renewals for the book 'Men Without Country', published the same year, are credited to Hall and Nordhoff.  We have not seen how the article is credited in the magazine.

renewed-contributions.title: The Stork, the Goose, the Eagle and the Swan
Since We Can Neither Run Nor Ride
Historians at Work: Brooks and Henry Adams
The Man Who Shot Snapping Turtles
Mrs. Willoughby on the Plains of Troy
How I Acquired My Lack of Poise

additional-note: A 1971 renewal for the book 'The Little Locksmith' by Katherine Butler Hathaway notes that it was published serially in the Atlantic Monthly from September 1942 to January 1943.  This renewal is likely to be too late to cover the magazine publication; however, there were renewals filed for the magazine issues themselves.
